newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SIMEX Eurodollar, Euroyen in limbo on stable rates.
newsitem.headline: SIMEX Eurodollar, Euroyen in limbo on stable rates.

text.p: SIMEX Eurodollars and Euroyen futures were trapped in limbo on Thursday after the Federal Reserve left U.S. rates unchanged, dealers said.
Dealers said a lack of fresh news after Tuesday's Federal Open Market Committee meeting kept most players sidelined, resulting in a dismal Eurodollars futures.
However, they said they hoped U.S. jobless claims data, due later on Thursday, could provide some fresh trading incentive.
December Eurodollars ended up two ticks from their IMM close at 94.23 while March was up a tick, at 94.10.
Total turnover for the two contracts was at 10,100 lots.
Euroyen faired better than Eurodollars in terms of activity, dealers said.
After trading in a narrow band, December Euroyen ended at 99.16, up four ticks from its CME close. March was at 98.93, up a tick from its CME close.
Turnover for December and March Euroyen was at 8,700 and 6,800 lots respectively.
A dealer said a Japanese newspaper report suggesting that the Bank of Japan might hike rates was quickly dismissed as unfounded. The market focus was now on the August 28 Tankan.

The market expectation was for the Japanese economy to continue to show a gradual improvement. Expectations were for the Bank of Japan to maintain short-term rates or at worse, increase them by a quarter percentage point.
The Japanese government bond (JGB) futures made another feeble attempt to break 121.00 resistance but failed.
After inching to a high at 120.94, September JGB ended at 120.74, down 19 ticks from previous. Turnover was light at 378 lots.
